commentBody:
One of those puzzles where I had absolutely nothing on the first pass Across the top, thought I had maybe a Down or two, and then started connecting, half wondering where I knew some of the words from, but then wondering why they had come so hard at the start. For me, that's a fine Saturday puzzle, but not 16D. 

Thanks, Byron.
One of the hardest Saturdays I can remember. So few gimmes. Satisfying to finally finish, with some clever cluing, but felt like passing a kidney stone.
I enjoyed this one. I had very little at first but managed to complete it in a decent time.
This one was very challenging but satisfying in the end, and none of the cluing felt obnoxious once I figured it out. Well done.

Absolutely loved the clue for BANDS! 

Go Gunners!

Nine debut entries, including four excellent spanners, along with fabulous clues like ‚Äú46 years" and ‚ÄúGreen Suit‚Äù made this one of my favorite themeless puzzles.  

I HAVE TO BE HONEST and say it was not BETTER THAN SEX, but darn satisfying, nevertheless. 

That episode of M*A*S*H (Adam‚Äôs Ribs) is one of my favorites.. Alan Alda‚Äôs ‚Äúliver or fish" rant is classic. 

Great to have a Saturday offering from a veteran constructor. A perfect follow-up to yesterday‚Äôs impressive debut.

Thanks, Byron.

My that was hard.  "Smooth and fairly navigable"?  I don't think so!

I had pretty much nothing (besides a growing terror) until I gave in and completed the lower right ahead of schedule.

Unlike yesterday's hard and rewarding debut masterpiece, I can't say I really enjoyed this one at all.  The answers were just there for the sake of being there and fitting the space, like Greg Brady just fitting the suit.

Even rescanning it now I don't see anything clever or fun.  It was just a hard puzzle.  So it has that going for it.  Which is nice.

This was one of the hardest Saturdays in a long while for me‚Äîalmost double yesterday‚Äôs time, for all the talk of how difficult that was. I had almost nothing on my first, second and third passes and a lot of what I had was wrong‚ÄîMOURNING for Shiva (I was thinking Jewish before Hindu, go figure), I thought about some kind of DOTS on the Mocap suit, I guessed PAUL before PIUS, CRACY before ARCHY. I think all I really had was AHITUNA, MEL Ferrer and N‚ÄîB ( who knows the NOOB  spelling du jour). I guess I owe Austin Powers a debt of gratitude because if BADMOJO hadn‚Äôt popped in my brain not sure how I would have broken into this grid, you never know where your inspiration will come from!
Anyways that got the ball rolling and slowly but surely it filled in. Surprisingly as hard as it was there was nothing obscure to me except SUNRA (and it‚Äôs unfair to ask this Cincinnatian  in P&G land to think of any coffees besides Folgers). Great spanners in this grid, all of them. At  the end of the day an enjoyable challenge but I HAVETO BE HONEST not 16 D either

Definitely fair clueing. The issue really came down to having genuinely unique answers and very unique clues amongst the polysimnsy of the English language. 

I felt as though the clues did play to the gut feelings, however, the second guessing is what pinched the victory from or maybe for me. 

I knew the coins had to be either Oregon in nature or possibly Tsarist Russia. Which both make sense since there were Russian settlers on the west coast. 

Very glad to have to think.  It‚Äôs good to go to bed knowing I‚Äôve been stumped.
I loved this puzzle! Saturdays haven't been exercising my brain for a bit and this felt fair but with a little bite. Two thumbs up!
Solid, solid Saturday workout and a perfect example of the 'Tough But Fair' category of puzzles.

This is definitely a legit Saturday puzzle, the kind where you think that there is no hope at the outset, scramble for a foothold, and wrestle your way to the happy music with persistence and some opportune guesses (after abandoning some bad ones). Paired with yesterday‚Äôs surprisingly chewy puzzle, this is shaping up to be the toughest weekend of the year for me. Let‚Äôs see what Sunday has in store‚Ä¶

This was a wonderful solving experience! Got started (finally!) with ARCHY and DDAY and SCALENE but only after a couple of passes with nothing! My very last fill was the ‚ÄúS‚Äù in the middle of SENSORS when it finally dawned on me that mocap was short for motion capture. Thanks Bryan, for giving us this chance to work our puzzle muscles!

I always have so much to say, and then I navigate away from the puzzle to the Wordplay column and the comments, and I forget everything because the puzzle is gone.

This is the hardest Saturday I can remember solving, or rather, having the stubborness to solve to keep a streak alive.
Now that's more like it!
First time in a long while I‚Äôve needed the column to get a handle somewhere.
Love it when a Saturday constructor wrecks my average solving time! Nicely done. Clever clues, absolutely solveable with some brain twisting.

Glad to see the last few Saturdays have had some teeth. Happy to say I got through this one about fifteen minutes faster than last Saturday but was still way above my average. Overall excellent themeless puzzles this month. Keep bringing these constructors back editors!

Tough 40 minute solve. It's a rare instance that I have a full grid where everything that looks right but no golf star. On my second pass, I found my mistake. CAREr/STYLErS looked right by was wrong.

Two tennis clues make me happy. 6D was a gimme. I only saw the movie 5 times when it was in theaters. Twice for Zendaya, twice for the tennis, and the fifth time because it was just that good. 37D took me a few seconds to figure out, though. Is that a debut answer?

34D should have been a gimme, but I filled 39A first and took way too long to delete cracy.

If I can get Gold Stars on Sunday (and Monday), my streak will hit 100 Days!
When every clue is a riddle and unable to have definitive clues to build from, it‚Äôs just not enjoyable.
Boy, sounds like I might be in the minority having found this one easier than yesterday. ‚ÄúGreen suit‚Äù is an all-timer!
I‚Äôve just finished my first look-over and have a grand total of 0 answers. I don‚Äôt understand how people get any of these clues, let alone all of them!

That one was just the right amount of crunchy for me.  Grabbed a handful of reasonable guesses on the first pass, most of which eventually proved correct.  But had that awful feeling I might have to get some help from Google.  But ever so gradually it all fell into place with no lookups - SW, then SE, most of NE, long answers, finally NW.  A satisfying solve, rven if not particularly quick.

@SBK

üëçüèΩ

Look, I‚Äôve just started this one, but after one little pass I‚Äôm delighted to have a small handful of likely-correct guesses, including one that reminds me of my grandmother offering her Sunday afternoon guests a cup of SANKA. (This from the woman who once asked me if I was wearing ‚Äúpaint,‚Äù because that‚Äôs what they called it way back in the 20s. And I was 15 in 1986!) Anyway, I also got NOOB and MEL and SUN RA ‚Äî and I HAVE TO BE HONEST, I‚Äôm going to bed with a feeling of satisfaction and something to look forward to tomorrow morning. (Now if only I‚Äôd thought to drink decaf this afternoon instead of regular, while pushing through the last dregs of the work week. Maybe I will stay up to finish, after all‚Ä¶)

IHAVETOBEHONEST . . .

ICANTTALK!

This puzzle!  WOW!

The Blue Jays! HOW?

That commercial during the game! POW!

Miracles do happen, and we can rally 'round the truth.

Harder than yesterday by about 20 minutes.

Alternative clue for 7D: "The forensic detectives found no blood ___ _____."

Had to dig deep on this one! Great wordplay. For new-ish solvers this is a puzzle where you might need to throw some guesses out there, try to get a cross, and give yourself a toehold. That gets easier with experience and you can spot more letter patterns quickly. As always, I can't relate to the "obnoxious" or "annoying" comments. This took me more than my average time, but at no point did I find it boring. It's the NYT Saturday puzzle, it's supposed to be a challenge, and this was a superb example!

I'm sorry, who is supposed to know this trivia?
Zero foothold to be had for your average human.

Some Saturdays are doable but this isn't one of them.

Loved this one, and found it a lot more gratifying than last Saturday's. I have to say that I really don't mind the riddle-like clues as much as some other people seem to. I find them really satisfying, and I think it's a lot more fair to have riddle-type clues than Naticks or a glut of proper names. Thanks Byron!
More puzzle than crossword...

Really enjoyed this Saturday puzzle. At first I was stymied but eventually butchered my way through it. Better than sex helped a lot. I love Saturday‚Äôs because there‚Äôs no gimmicks you have to solve it all the way through. I laughed at green suit couldn‚Äôt figure it out at first. Great puzzle.

This almost made me break the no lookups rule. 

You know it‚Äôs going to be hard when even UNO isn‚Äôt the card shout. SCALENE was my way in. But nothing else was there to get going. 

An awful lot of trivia but in the end with patience and perseverance it was doable. 

SANKA with SUNRA was a bit unfair but it fell last and there were not that many phonetically appropriate options. 

17A. The era of civility. I do miss it. Not a political statement, just about manners.

Very gratifying solve! One of those puzzles where I have zero toeholds on my first pass, then slowly chip away after a few big guesses that trigger other guesses which trigger others. (Though having SANKA cross SUNRA was rough, as someone unfamiliar with both. That S was the last to fall before the music played.)

What an interesting experience!

My first across and down pass yielded almost nothing. The second pass changed little. I felt dejected. There's no way I will ever be able to complete this, I thought. Could this possibly be the hardest puzzle I have ever seen at the NYT? 

So I did what I usually do in such cases - I looked up most of the trivia and other arcana: RAMADAN (doh! Of course I knew it, but not as clued...), SAL, DAMES, CARET, SANKA, MEL, MADAMEX, PHILO, UNE, SCALENE, and SUNRA.

With those mysteries out of the way, I was able to deal with the grid very quickly, and I enjoyed it very much. The clueing was possibly NOT BETTER THAN S3X, but it wasn't half bad at all. 

I was proud of myself for figuring out OREGON TERRITORY with just a few crosses. I've never heard of beaver coins, but the name sounds so siIIy that I love it ü§™

Didn't really vibe with this puzzle but finally got through it in a little over an hour. It's one of those crafty puzzles that is not really hard in retrospect, just had a hard time nailing down enough crosses at first. Took a couple breaks to let the "little grey cells" do their thing, et voila!
This felt like the Everest of crosswords. One day I hope to reach a peak like this on my own intelligence...for today I relied on the Sherpas of the Wordplay column and Google.

On the first pass the only clues I got were ONE and ENO. Then after all the trivia lookups (they were so obscure that lookups were pretty much mandatory), I had enough to piece the rest together.
It was difficult mainly because so many of the answers were so obscure, not because of the wicked wordplay of yesterday's puzzle.
Bottom half was bear.
I particularly liked 9 Down.

I'm here to say that edamame was not particularly helpful fill for 
2 D, and other than SANKA (thanks to my waitressing days) and SUN RA, that's about all I had after my first pass.  

This was one of those puzzles I just had to RASSLE to the ground, bit by bit, which makes for my favorite type of Saturday puzzle.

POY material?  I'm putting it in my folder.

Almost un-doable for me, not that that's a complaint, my ignorance.

Instead of looking up, I reveal one letter and guess a likely combination of sounds. It often works. Except names like PHILO that are not familiar.

Sometimes the clue and the solution are both too obscure for me, like mocap, cursed vibe, and vacuum tubes (for a vacuum cleaner?) and does ORDER UP refer to food or baseball (having learnt that plate is used)? 

I think a lot of the clues were fine, just not for me.
GETTO=bug?  Help me out‚Ä¶
This seems to be one of those puzzles that is made more difficult than it should be with vague clues.

Wow. That was a beast. Literally not one square filled first pass. I needed all the help I could get from Wordplay to even get started. Admittedly I was never going to guess the product names, obscure coinage etc etc, but it was fun trying to battle through. 

It‚Äôs pheasant season here from today. The Alpacas are experiencing gentlemen in plus fours with loud sticks happily downing these beautiful, dumb birds in the woods next to their field. After a wander over for a group look, they‚Äôve returned to grazing quite peacefully. I will never understand the allure of this ‚Äòsport‚Äô. Most of them don‚Äôt even want to eat the birds. They pose for a photo ala big game hunter with a pile of carcasses, then go back from whence they came. Odd.
It was tough but fair. As a former restaurant worker, Sanka was my first fill!

Not sure why, but this was the toughest grid in years for me.

Totally impenetrable.

Not sure if that represents praise or criticism.
After Friday, another solid challenge. Made it through with crossers and guesses, but some of the trivia was excessive.
Tough tough tough!!  Some of those I never would have got. Hate having to cheat!! üò©üò©

ENO makes an almost unhealthy amount of appearances in the NYT crossword‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs annoying. 
Does he know about this!?!
Biden Presidency?  He was the 46th president, but that's not 46 years.  I got frustrated by this misfired clue.

Oh. My. Goodness! This was tough! But looking back over it, it all makes sense. I loved the ONE and ENO pairing. And the Beaver coins. Such a fun puzzle, even though I had to cheat more than I like to. Y‚Äôall have a wonderful Saturday! It‚Äôs cold this morning but it‚Äôs going to be a beautiful day here in our mountains. Thanks, Byron!

Mocap artist here with a slight technical gripe. Many‚Äîarguably most‚Äîmotion capture suits do not have sensors. They have optical markers like little reflective balls, LEDs, or visual patterns. All the "sensing" is done externally, with cameras.

Only a handful of systems work with IMU sensors attached to the suit itself.

Just as with yesterday‚Äôs puzzle, I look at the finished grid and there are hardly any answers I haven‚Äôt heard of, but to get from the blank grid to that finished grid, I had to break through a barricade of riddles.

But there is a difference.  Yesterday, with its effervescent wordplay, felt like a party.  Today felt like scratch and claw.

And I like both.

Today for me had a Rollercoaster Moment, where you‚Äôve been fussing and laboring, grinding like a rollercoaster climbing its initial huge hill, then it reaches the apex and is motionless for a precious instant, and then comes the ‚ÄúWheeee!‚Äù

Suddenly, in the puzzle, you fill something in, and from the crosses it produces, the curtains fall, and bam bam bam what was opaque is suddenly obvious, and for a bit, answers cascade in a begat-fest.  Heaven.

The grid has the fine Walden trademarks ‚Äì answers from a wide range of fields, uber-vague clues buttressed  by some uber-witty wordplay clues, and a remarkably junk-free grid.

All melding into the experience I hope for on Saturday.  Byron, your puzzles after 24 years in the Times, are sharp as ever.  You are a treasure.  Thank you for another splendid outing!

I guess only doing Thursday, Friday and Saturday puzzles as they come out and using the archives to go backward is honing my skills. I immediately got 17A because a part of my brain has begun to think like the clever constructors. That really helped early on.

I really enjoyed the puzzle. Completing it in just over 30 minutes gets my Saturday off to a fantastic start. Since I don‚Äôt get to talk to people in my life who do the NYT puzzle, is that a good time?
Can anyone explain 17A? I don't get it.

(It's sad that the emus won't allow words that are, in fact, entries in the puzzle. EP version:) At the very beginning of my career, I worked at a bakery/coffee shop which offered a chocolate "Better Than Sacks" cake. But that was in the late 1980s. Even at the time, I found the name a little tacky; my thought was: "well, maybe better than sacks with YOU . . ." Funny, just last evening I was reading about reconstructed ancient vessels: triremes, quinqueremes, Viking longships. For anyone who wants something a little more literary than The History Channel's *Vikings*, may I recommend *The Long Ships*, by Frans Bengtsson (1941-45, Eng. 1954). When I read it as a wee child, I found it a thrilling, and often funny, adventure novel . . . returning to it a couple years ago, and knowing more about European history of the "Dark" Ages, I found it . . .a thrilling, and often funny, adventure novel! Christa Grix, the music programmer at WRCJ, our local Classical/Jazz radio station, produces, writes, and narrates two-minute educational spots which find commonalities between the two genres. Here's one she did comparing Alexander Skriabin and Sun-Ra: https://soundcloud.com/wrcj909fmhd1/christa-grix-scriabin-sun-ra?in=wrcj909fmhd1/sets/christa-grix-features
The emus don't like me today.
I would like to personally thank Will Shortz for giving us both a Friday and a Saturday puzzle this week that were worthy of their placement at the end of the week.

Very hard one for me. Way slower than my average, almost to my Sunday average.

I don't think I had anything before SANKA and MEL, and each row and section was hard won.

Much of the trivia, or what I considered trivia (MADAMEX, for instance), fell just on the right side of the obscure/unfair line. It took me a while to remember that Mr. Farnsworth's name was not Perry or Percy, but PHILO, although I realize that I should have filled in the only Muslim month I know way sooner than I did.

By contrast, since I'm already seeing the comparisons, I really enjoyed yesterday and beat my Friday average.

For some reason I'm still totally blanked on Strands, but I have the rest of the day for that.

Which was harder, Friday or Saturday?

Looks like they got it wrong this time.  Friday's puzzle appears to be a bit tougher (which jibes with my personal experience as well).
I wish I could say I liked this puzzle. Too esoteric. But maybe it‚Äôs just me. Just when I think I‚Äôm getting competent at Saturdays something like this shows up.

From Caitlin:

‚Äú‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs actually smooth and fairly navigable‚Äù. 

Huh. Could‚Äôve fooled me. But I was glad that I got through it!

Not up on my beaver coin history or movie musicals from 91 years ago, I'm afraid. I think I looked up about half of this one, and I struggled with the rest. Congratulations to those who completed it cleanly. I will never be that good.
I guess someone is going to have to explain "BIDENPRESIDENCY" to me 46?

So good! Instead of parsing groaner-level puns, I actually learned stuff. These days the first thing I do upon opening the puzzle is to scan the clues for question marks. The more question marks, the more homonyms and parts-of-speech tricks ‚Äî and then I know I have a dull solving slog ahead.

@SBK,

You must be on cloud nine (runs) today! What an inning! 

And with Shohei‚Äôs home run, there was something for everyone. 

Hats off to the Jays today. üß¢ ‚öæÔ∏è

On my first pass, I had ONE, ENO and SANKA followed by AHI TUNA, MADAME X, LODE and N__B. Poke is popular with my family and prevalent in my neck of the woods. This summer we went to The Met and saw the John Singer Sargent exhibit which included the MADAME X painting. The story behind it was fascinating to me. I wasn‚Äôt able to add much more to the grid before I fell asleep. Woke up this morning and as usual, the answers started flowing. I‚Äôm still fascinated that my brain ruminates on the puzzle overnight and answers start coming to me. 

On a side note, I was so excited to see Will Klein pitch last night! He was the college baseball player that lived with us during the summer of 2019 when he played for the Chinooks in the Northwoods League. I couldn‚Äôt have been more proud if he was my own son ü§©
These clues are too coquettish for me.
This is what Grammy Hall would call a real Saturday

Great grid and puzzle. I had a hard time getting a toehold but HINDUGOD got me started in the SE and I pretty much went clockwise from there. And TIL that PANDA is UK slang for police car which was an ‚Äúoh yeah‚Äù moment and I will definitely start using.
Aargh! This felt like the longest 1:20:14 of my life. My brain hurts...

Solved this unaided, but quite a workout. Took me almost twice as long as yesterday's puzzle.

Perhaps the two most challenging back-to-back puzzles in a long time. Much appreciated!

As a mathematician, I got SCALENE quickly. But was then completely misdirected by "Combinations with numbers and sets" for BANDS. Well played there.

Excellent Saturday puzzle!
I done did this puzz....(and I really dint expect to finish, but I did! Quality ThFS's are back it seems! ü•≥)
God bless everyone who completes this puzzle without ‚Äúauto-check‚Äù  turned on. You are better people than I am.

This is a bad puzzle.

Saturdays are supposed to be hard, sure. But the volume of esoteric trivia involved here really just means that the puzzle is borderline impossible without looking things up. Even after filling the tricky clues, there were probably 5-10 crossed naticks that require random knowledge.

A puzzle like this needs to have a theme or some other mechanism so that the solver can reason out the clues without resorting to looking things up. It's really just not fun.

Oof.

I confidently filled in RAMADAN at 1A, but things went very quickly downhill. My first pass left me with about three answers filled in. Things got a bit DICEY in the center-west, but I'm one of those DAMES who never gives up. In the end I RASSLED the puzzle into submission.

FYI, I've had BETTER THAN SEX cake, and it's not.
17 across makes no sense‚Ä¶.

This is a reminder to me that Saturdays are supposed to be too difficult for me. 
I dislike puzzles with long answers that are expressions. I gave this about 10 minutes, then "revealed puzzle" to see the answers I never would have gotten.
The puzzle creator did a good job, it's just not for me.

This was tough. I couldn‚Äôt get past thinking the beaver coin was Canada-related and that Shiva was referring to something Jewish (a theologian I am not‚Ä¶) 

It took me over 30 minutes to solve. Someday I will learn my lesson and not begin solving right before bed because my brain works better in the morning. When I continued this morning, things came much faster.

Any time anyone says BETTER THAN SEX or something similar, I‚Äôm reminded of the episode of It‚Äôs Always Sunny where they try to emulate the new trendy bar in town.
Just under an hour, but pleased when I got there. To those xwstats prodigies who did this in 25 minutes, I can only confess my envy.

It was so impenetrable for me that I had to go into the archives and do some Monday puzzles just to reassure myself that I had a brain ü§£
Just not a Saturday brain.
I thought Friday was pretty easy, for me this one was not at all comparable.

I was going to post a triangle pun, but I'm scalene back on those.

(This is acute comment.)

Wowie Zowie, was that ever a hard puzzle!  It's the best part of an hour that I'll never get back, but I'm feeling pretty chuffed that I solved it at all.  I did quail a moment or two when I saw the constructor's by-line, and I went down a few rabbit holes, took the bait, fell for the misdirection, and failed to catch the trick-- again and again--until Voila!  Finis!  
No old white head for your trophy wall, Byron; better luck next time!

Okay, I guess that's enough.  I *do* have a few other things to do today...

35 mins slower than my average is the kind of pain I want to feel when doing a Saturday puzzle.

Easily one of the most satisfying puzzles of the year. Amirite?
A fun puzzle: https://www.davidkwongmagic.com/crosswordsetc

Relieved to see that for once I'm not the only one who found this to be a tough puzzle. Long workout, and I had to look some things up. Nine debut answers - don't recall the last time I saw that; at least some of those were not terribly unfamiliar. And... my puzzle find today. A Sunday from July 11, 2021 by Ashish Vengsarkar with the title: "NO RUSE." Some theme clue and answer examples: "Onus for a magician's disappearing act?" BURDENOFPOOF "Dramatic accusation at a dentist's office?" YOUCANTHANDLETHETOOTH "Angry Wisconsin sports fans?" MILWAUKEEBOOERS "Getting "Amscray!" under control?" TAMINGOFTHESHOO "Power of a cowboy's shoe?" BOOTSTRENGTH Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/11/2021&g=40&d=D ...
I'd like to file a complaint about BADJOJO...clearly the cluing should have referred to "Messy Siwa" or something, but BADJUJU is another thing entirely.

Surprised to see so many comments about how tough this one was, given I finished 5 mins under my Saturday average. I think I was just on the constructor‚Äôs wavelength for the top half of the puzzle because 1, 8, 15, and 17A were all immediate gimmes. For me, ‚Äú46 years‚Äù was obvious! But maybe that‚Äôs because I think about 45/47 too much.

It‚Äôs always immensely satisfying when I am seemingly stuck on a Saturday with about half the grid to go, give in to fatigue, then wake up fresh and solve the last half with determined fang and claw.

7 minutes over average. Excellent puzzle. Full marks for fun!

And that was an easy peasy hard sudoku! The top third filled in short order.

I‚Äôm in Natick (!) for the day at a speedcubing competition with my son, and while the kids are solving one set of cubic puzzle, I‚Äôm working on another. Thanks for a fine Saturday morning, Byron Walden.

Cannot believe I managed this one - one of my most proud solves, especially as a relatively younger solver. I didn't know any of the trivia but SUNRA fell into place once I had S_NRA. Hard but fair, an hour of my Saturday morning that I don't regret!

Oof. And I thought Friday was a butt kicker. I had 5 fills on my first pass, and 3 of them were wrong. (I can only take credit for ONE, as ENO was a gimme.)

On days like this, all I can do is consult Professor Google for the answers that can be looked up, and then use what remains as an opportunity to practice my wordplay skills. I can‚Äôt say this was a lot of fun, but for the mental challenge alone it was still worthwhile.

Needed way too much help to say I solved it. Like if we had golf like handicap for crossword, I‚Äôd say I needed a 12 shot start. It would be like saying I swam the lake in a yacht‚Äôs jacuzzi. Like saying I beat Usain Bolt starting at the 90 meter line. Like saying I‚Äôm an investment genius in this out of whack stock market. Like I cooked a dish in microwave. Like that

Marvelous, marvelous challenge. A few minutes below average but felt much more difficult. My kind of puzzle. 

Yesterday was also a great ride...thank you to both constructors and to Will Shortz for giving us some bona fide stuff to chew on.

I went to bed last night with an almost empty grid and a sinking feeling that I would have to resort to Google and Wordplay to get me to the end, but we have a 2 1/2 hour drive and I got to work on the puzzle while my wife drove.  Slowly, painfully it came together.  I was about 9 minutes slower than my average but it felt like longer.  
Just like yesterday, I‚Äôm glad I stuck with it and was guilty of the sin of pride when I was done.  (Just kidding. To misquote Gordon Gekko: pride is good.)

A ‚Äúrule‚Äù I have come to rely on is that when a clue calls for what looks like hopelessly obscure trivia for most people, the answer will be the most (or only) obvious one. For example, of the ten unmentioned months of the Islamic calendar, 1A is the one most of us know, not the nine we don‚Äôt. And the 48A beaver coin almost has to be from a North American political jurisdiction with a name 15 letters long. That almost forces it to end in TERRITORY (no one says Alberta Province). Indian could work, but not too many beavers in Oklahoma; I wanted Youkon, but the spelling was DICEY. I realize that what I‚Äôm saying is pretty obvious, but I just want to make the point that the Gray Lady tends to play fair even on Friday and Saturday. Great puzzle.

Saturdays are back, baby ‚Äî that‚Äôs three great ones in a row!

I was absolutely not on the constructor‚Äôs wavelength on this one and had *very* few gimmes (AHITUNA, NOOB, and HINDOGOD are the only ones I can immediately remember), but was still able to piece it together slowly but surely ‚Äî the mark of a well-constructed Friday/Saturday offering.

When my family lived in Dallas in the 1970s, my sister (who did not have a great sense of direction) once wanted to visit her boyfriend in Beaumont, Texas. He sent her written directions to take Interstate 45 south from Dallas (towards Houston), but to exit I-45 at Corsicana (a smallish city about 50 miles south of Dallas).

My sister misread the directions and thought she was supposed to exit I-45 at ‚ÄúLouisiana.‚Äù (Which, as I think you know, is a state.)

Motion capture ... as in modern film making I assume.

Yeah, turns out it's a suit studded with sensors that, after an actor's movements in the suit are recorded and the footage is analyzed, enables the digitization of that motion. Which allows the same motion to be applied, for instance, to an animated character.

@Dan
Actually, the answer is wrong. MoCap suits are covered in markers. (The early versions looked like ping=pong balls.) The SENSORS are positioned around the actor wearing the suit, and track the movement of those markers. So Robert Downey Jr isn't really wearing the Iron Man armor when he's hovering ten feet off the ground.
